senses.de: Something that happens or appears because of something else
senses.ex: Eating too much sugar often results in tooth decay.

Tips.title: Cause and Effect
Tips.description: Use 'result' to link an action directly to its consequence.
Tips.example: Lack of sleep can result in lower concentration.

Tips.title: Phrase Linking
Tips.description: Combine 'as a result' with a semicolon to join two related sentences.
Tips.example: It rained heavily; as a result, the game was canceled.

senses.de: To happen or exist because of something else
senses.ex: His hard work resulted in his promotion.

Tips.title: Reasoning Consequence
Tips.description: Use 'resulted in' to show a logical outcome of a situation.
Tips.example: The new strategy resulted in increased sales.

Tips.title: Impersonal Subjects
Tips.description: With 'results in', the subject is often an event or action, not a person.
Tips.example: The new law results in better protection for wildlife.

senses.de: The outcome of an activity or process
senses.ex: The election results came as a shock to the ruling party.

Tips.title: Reporting Outcomes
Tips.description: Use 'the results of' when talking about information gained from a study or test.
Tips.example: The results of the survey will be published soon.

Tips.title: Surprising Element
Tips.description: Express unexpected outcomes by emphasizing 'result' in the sentence.
Tips.example: Their experimental approach had amazing results.

senses.de: To end in a particular way
senses.ex: The competition resulted in a draw.

Tips.title: Final Outcome
Tips.description: Employ 'resulted in' when summarizing the ending of an event.
Tips.example: The negotiations resulted in a settlement.

Tips.title: Undecided Finale
Tips.description: Use 'resulted in a draw' to describe an event with no clear winner.
Tips.example: The chess match resulted in a draw.

senses.de: To be the final calculation after application of a mathematical operation
senses.ex: Adding five and four results in nine.

Tips.title: Mathematical Use
Tips.description: In math, 'result' refers to the answer obtained from calculations.
Tips.example: What does adding these two numbers result in?

Tips.title: Abstract Concepts
Tips.description: Use 'result' in academic contexts to discuss outcomes of abstract processes.
Tips.example: Her hypothesis resulted in a groundbreaking theory.

Conclusion.wordDefinition:
Conclusion and result are different in terms of their meaning and use.

Conclusion refers to a decision or an opinion based on facts, evidence, or reasoning. It is the final outcome of a process of thinking or investigation.

A conclusion is often drawn after considering all the available information and evaluating it critically. For example, after conducting a scientific experiment, a conclusion can be made about the findings and what it indicates.

Conclusion is used when drawing an opinion based on facts and evidence, while result is used when referring to the outcome of an action or event.

Consequence.wordDefinition:
Consequence and result are both words that describe the outcome of a particular action or event.

Consequence generally refers to a negative outcome or effect that stems directly from something that someone does. For example, if you skip school, the consequence might be that you fail a test or get detention.

Consequence is often used to describe negative outcomes, while result is more general and can refer to any outcome.

Effect.wordDefinition:
Effect generally refers to the impact or influence that one thing has upon another thing or situation. For instance, if someone takes a medication and experiences certain side effects, those are the consequences of taking the medication.

Or, if a business decision is made that causes a change in the company's profits, that change is the effect of the decision.

Both words can be used in a variety of contexts and have similar meanings, but effect is generally used to describe the broader impact or influence of something, while result is used to specifically indicate what happens as a consequence of an action or event.

Fruit.wordDefinition:
Fruit refers to the edible part of a plant that contains seeds, such as apples, oranges, and bananas.

To simplify, fruit describes food that comes from plants, and result describes the outcome of any process or event.

Outcome.wordDefinition:
Both the words outcome and result refer to something that happens as a consequence of an action or decision.

However, outcome generally refers to the final consequence or the end result of an event or activity. It typically involves a longer timeframe and often involves multiple smaller results.

For example, the outcome of a football game is the final score or which team won, while the result of a team's goal scoring is one team gaining an advantage over the other.

Product.wordDefinition:
Product usually refers to something tangible that is produced or manufactured, such as a computer, a book or a piece of furniture.

Both words can be applicable in different contexts. Product is generally more commonly used in the context of business and manufacturing, while result is commonly used in the context of scientific experiments, research studies and personal development.

Product refers to the physical or tangible output of a process or activity, while result refers to the outcomes or consequences of that process or activity.

Repercussion.wordDefinition:
Repercussion refers to a negative or unintended consequence that follows an action or decision. For example, if you decide to skip class to go to a party, the repercussion could be getting a detention or falling behind in your studies.

Repercussion emphasizes the negative consequences of an action or decision, while result simply refers to the outcome.

Solution.wordDefinition:
A result is the outcome of something that happens, while a solution is the answer to a problem or situation.

However, if you are struggling with a math problem, finding the correct answer is the solution to the problem.

A result is applicable when you are talking about something that already happened or occurred, while a solution is applicable when talking about how to solve or fix something.

Upshot.wordDefinition:
It can refer to any outcome, whether positive or negative. Upshot is a more specific term that usually describes the final or ultimate consequence of a series of events or decisions.

It often implies that the outcome was inevitable or unavoidable. For example, "the result of the game was a tie" vs "the upshot of the negotiations was that they agreed to sign the contract".

quotes.Text: Let everyone try and find that as a result of daily prayer he adds something new to his life, something with which nothing can be compared.
quotes.Title: Indian Leader
quotes.Name: Mahatma Gandhi

quotes.Text: Character is the result of two things: mental attitude and the way we spend our time.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Elbert Hubbard

quotes.Text: Freedom across the world is a result of many individuals working together.
quotes.Title: American Wrestler
quotes.Name: Dan Gable

quotes.Text: Creative projects are rarely the result of a single person's efforts.
quotes.Title: American Artist
quotes.Name: Trevor Paglen

quotes.Text: What is important in life is life, and not the result of life.
quotes.Title: German Writer
quotes.Name: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

quotes.Text: In the world of football only the results are important.
quotes.Title: Spanish Athlete
quotes.Name: Sergio Busquets

quotes.Text: Belief that influences behavior influences results.
quotes.Title: American Coach
quotes.Name: Tom Herman

quotes.Text: What I am is a direct result of how I was raised.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Troy Aikman

quotes.Text: As a team, the most important thing is results.
quotes.Title: Spanish Athlete
quotes.Name: Hector Bellerin

quotes.Text: The result showed the wisdom of your orders.
quotes.Title: American Lawyer
quotes.Name: John Bigelow
